ranked_diseases.explanation: The patient presents with cortical tubers, angiofibromas, and renal angiomyolipoma, which are hallmark features of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC). TSC1 is one of the major genetic causes of this condition.
Similar to TSC1, TSC2 is another major genetic cause of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex, presenting with cortical tubers, angiofibromas, and renal angiomyolipoma.
Although less likely, Birt-Hogg-Dube Syndrome can present with renal tumors (including angiomyolipomas) and skin lesions, but cortical tubers are not typically associated with this condition.
Neurofibromatosis Type 1 can present with skin lesions and tumors, but cortical tubers and renal angiomyolipomas are not typical features, making this a less likely diagnosis.
Sturge-Weber Syndrome can present with cortical abnormalities and skin lesions, but renal angiomyolipomas are not a feature of this condition.
